member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.Factorization.DenseEvd
member.summary: Eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a complex matrix.
member.remarks: If A is Hermitian, then A = V*D*V' where the eigenvalue matrix D is diagonal and the eigenvector matrix V is Hermitian. I.e. A = V*D*V' and V*VH=I. If A is not symmetric, then the eigenvalue matrix D is block diagonal with the real eigenvalues in 1-by-1 blocks and any complex eigenvalues, lambda + i*mu, in 2-by-2 blocks, [lambda, mu; -mu, lambda]. The columns of V represent the eigenvectors in the sense that A*V = V*D, i.e. A.Multiply(V) equals V.Multiply(D). The matrix V may be badly conditioned, or even singular, so the validity of the equation A = V*D*Inverse(V) depends upon V.Condition().

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.Factorization.Evd
member.summary: Eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a real matrix.
member.remarks: If A is symmetric, then A = V*D*V' where the eigenvalue matrix D is diagonal and the eigenvector matrix V is orthogonal. I.e. A = V*D*V' and V*VT=I. If A is not symmetric, then the eigenvalue matrix D is block diagonal with the real eigenvalues in 1-by-1 blocks and any complex eigenvalues, lambda + i*mu, in 2-by-2 blocks, [lambda, mu; -mu, lambda]. The columns of V represent the eigenvectors in the sense that A*V = V*D, i.e. A.Multiply(V) equals V.Multiply(D). The matrix V may be badly conditioned, or even singular, so the validity of the equation A = V*D*Inverse(V) depends upon V.Condition().

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.Factorization.LU

summary.para: A class which encapsulates the functionality of an LU factorization.
For a matrix A, the LU factorization is a pair of lower triangular matrix L and upper triangular matrix U so that A = L*U.
In the Math.NET implementation we also store a set of pivot elements for increased numerical stability. The pivot elements encode a permutation matrix P such that P*A = L*U.

member.remarks: The computation of the LU factorization is done at construction time.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.Factorization.LU.Determinant
member.summary: Gets the determinant of the matrix for which the LU factorization was computed.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.Factorization.QR

summary.para: A class which encapsulates the functionality of the QR decomposition.

Any real square matrix A (m x n) may be decomposed as A = QR where Q is an orthogonal matrix (its columns are orthogonal unit vectors meaning QTQ = I) and R is an upper triangular matrix (also called right triangular matrix).

member.remarks: The computation of the QR decomposition is done at construction time by Householder transformation. If a factorization is performed, the resulting Q matrix is an m x m matrix and the R matrix is an m x n matrix. If a factorization is performed, the resulting Q matrix is an m x n matrix and the R matrix is an n x n matrix.

member.summary: Gets the absolute determinant value of the matrix for which the QR matrix was computed.

member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the matrix is full rank or not.
member.value: true if the matrix is full rank; otherwise false.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.Factorization.UserGramSchmidt

summary.para: A class which encapsulates the functionality of the QR decomposition Modified Gram-Schmidt Orthogonalization.
Any complex square matrix A may be decomposed as A = QR where Q is an unitary mxn matrix and R is an nxn upper triangular matrix.

member.remarks: The computation of the QR decomposition is done at construction time by modified Gram-Schmidt Orthogonalization.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.Factorization.UserLU

summary.para: A class which encapsulates the functionality of an LU factorization.
For a matrix A, the LU factorization is a pair of lower triangular matrix L and upper triangular matrix U so that A = L*U.

member.remarks: The computation of the LU factorization is done at construction time.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.Factorization.UserQR

summary.para: A class which encapsulates the functionality of the QR decomposition.

Any real square matrix A may be decomposed as A = QR where Q is an orthogonal matrix (its columns are orthogonal unit vectors meaning QTQ = I) and R is an upper triangular matrix (also called right triangular matrix).

member.remarks: The computation of the QR decomposition is done at construction time by Householder transformation.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.Solvers.BiCgStab
member.summary: A Bi-Conjugate Gradient stabilized iterative matrix solver.

remarks.para:
The Bi-Conjugate Gradient Stabilized (BiCGStab) solver is an 'improvement' of the standard Conjugate Gradient (CG) solver. Unlike the CG solver the BiCGStab can be used on non-symmetric matrices.
Note that much of the success of the solver depends on the selection of the proper preconditioner.

The Bi-CGSTAB algorithm was taken from:
Templates for the solution of linear systems: Building blocks for iterative methods
Richard Barrett, Michael Berry, Tony F. Chan, James Demmel, June M. Donato, Jack Dongarra, Victor Eijkhout, Roldan Pozo, Charles Romine and Henk van der Vorst
Url: http://www.netlib.org/templates/Templates.html
Algorithm is described in Chapter 2, section 2.3.8, page 27
The example code below provides an indication of the possible use of the solver.

remarks.para:
Solver based on:
Faster PDE-based simulations using robust composite linear solvers
S. Bhowmicka, P. Raghavan a,*, L. McInnes b, B. Norris
Future Generation Computer Systems, Vol 20, 2004, pp 373387
Note that if an iterator is passed to this solver it will be used for all the sub-solvers.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.Solvers.GpBiCg
member.summary: A Generalized Product Bi-Conjugate Gradient iterative matrix solver.

remarks.para:
The Generalized Product Bi-Conjugate Gradient (GPBiCG) solver is an alternative version of the Bi-Conjugate Gradient stabilized (CG) solver. Unlike the CG solver the GPBiCG solver can be used on non-symmetric matrices.
Note that much of the success of the solver depends on the selection of the proper preconditioner.

The GPBiCG algorithm was taken from:
GPBiCG(m,l): A hybrid of BiCGSTAB and GPBiCG methods with efficiency and robustness
S. Fujino
Applied Numerical Mathematics, Volume 41, 2002, pp 107 - 117
The example code below provides an indication of the possible use of the solver.

The ILUTP-Mem algorithm was taken from:
ILUTP_Mem: a Space-Efficient Incomplete LU Preconditioner
Tzu-Yi Chen, Department of Mathematics and Computer Science,
Pomona College, Claremont CA 91711, USA
Published in:
Lecture Notes in Computer Science
Volume 3046 / 2004
pp. 20 - 28
Algorithm is described in Section 2, page 22

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.Solvers.ILUTPPreconditioner.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the default settings.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.Solvers.ILUTPPreconditioner.#ctor(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the specified settings.
member.param: The amount of fill that is allowed in the matrix. The value is a fraction of the number of non-zero entries in the original matrix. Values should be positive.

The absolute drop tolerance which indicates below what absolute value an entry will be dropped from the matrix. A drop tolerance of 0.0 means that no values will be dropped. Values should always be positive.
The pivot tolerance which indicates at what level pivoting will take place. A value of 0.0 means that no pivoting will take place.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.Solvers.ILUTPPreconditioner.FillLevel
member.summary: Gets or sets the amount of fill that is allowed in the matrix. The value is a fraction of the number of non-zero entries in the original matrix. The standard value is 200.

remarks.para: Values should always be positive and can be higher than 1.0. A value lower than 1.0 means that the eventual preconditioner matrix will have fewer non-zero entries as the original matrix. A value higher than 1.0 means that the eventual preconditioner can have more non-zero values than the original matrix.
Note that any changes to the FillLevel after creating the preconditioner will invalidate the created preconditioner and will require a re-initialization of the preconditioner.

member.exception: Thrown if a negative value is provided.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.Solvers.ILUTPPreconditioner.DropTolerance
member.summary: Gets or sets the absolute drop tolerance which indicates below what absolute value an entry will be dropped from the matrix. The standard value is 0.0001.

remarks.para: The values should always be positive and can be larger than 1.0. A low value will keep more small numbers in the preconditioner matrix. A high value will remove more small numbers from the preconditioner matrix.
Note that any changes to the DropTolerance after creating the preconditioner will invalidate the created preconditioner and will require a re-initialization of the preconditioner.

member.exception: Thrown if a negative value is provided.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex.Solvers.ILUTPPreconditioner.PivotTolerance
member.summary: Gets or sets the pivot tolerance which indicates at what level pivoting will take place. The standard value is 0.0 which means pivoting will never take place.

remarks.para: The pivot tolerance is used to calculate if pivoting is necessary. Pivoting will take place if any of the values in a row is bigger than the diagonal value of that row divided by the pivot tolerance, i.e. pivoting will take place if row(i,j) > row(i,i) / PivotTolerance for any j that is not equal to i.
Note that any changes to the PivotTolerance after creating the preconditioner will invalidate the created preconditioner and will require a re-initialization of the preconditioner.

member.exception: Thrown if a negative value is provided.

member.summary: Returns the upper triagonal matrix that was created during the LU decomposition.

member.returns: A new matrix containing the upper triagonal elements.

member.summary: A matrix type for diagonal matrices.
member.remarks: Diagonal matrices can be non-square matrices but the diagonal always starts at element 0,0. A diagonal matrix will throw an exception if non diagonal entries are set. The exception to this is when the off diagonal elements are 0.0 or NaN; these settings will cause no change to the diagonal matrix.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex32.Factorization.Cholesky

summary.para: A class which encapsulates the functionality of a Cholesky factorization.
For a symmetric, positive definite matrix A, the Cholesky factorization is an lower triangular matrix L so that A = L*L'.

member.remarks: The computation of the Cholesky factorization is done at construction time. If the matrix is not symmetric or positive definite, the constructor will throw an exception.

member.summary: Gets the log determinant of the matrix for which the Cholesky matrix was computed.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex32.Factorization.DenseEvd
member.summary: Eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a complex matrix.
member.remarks: If A is Hermitian, then A = V*D*V' where the eigenvalue matrix D is diagonal and the eigenvector matrix V is Hermitian. I.e. A = V*D*V' and V*VH=I. If A is not symmetric, then the eigenvalue matrix D is block diagonal with the real eigenvalues in 1-by-1 blocks and any complex eigenvalues, lambda + i*mu, in 2-by-2 blocks, [lambda, mu; -mu, lambda]. The columns of V represent the eigenvectors in the sense that A*V = V*D, i.e. A.Multiply(V) equals V.Multiply(D). The matrix V may be badly conditioned, or even singular, so the validity of the equation A = V*D*Inverse(V) depends upon V.Condition().

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex32.Factorization.DenseQR

summary.para: A class which encapsulates the functionality of the QR decomposition.

Any real square matrix A may be decomposed as A = QR where Q is an orthogonal matrix (its columns are orthogonal unit vectors meaning QTQ = I) and R is an upper triangular matrix (also called right triangular matrix).

member.remarks: The computation of the QR decomposition is done at construction time by Householder transformation.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex32.Factorization.Evd
member.summary: Eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a real matrix.
member.remarks: If A is symmetric, then A = V*D*V' where the eigenvalue matrix D is diagonal and the eigenvector matrix V is orthogonal. I.e. A = V*D*V' and V*VT=I. If A is not symmetric, then the eigenvalue matrix D is block diagonal with the real eigenvalues in 1-by-1 blocks and any complex eigenvalues, lambda + i*mu, in 2-by-2 blocks, [lambda, mu; -mu, lambda]. The columns of V represent the eigenvectors in the sense that A*V = V*D, i.e. A.Multiply(V) equals V.Multiply(D). The matrix V may be badly conditioned, or even singular, so the validity of the equation A = V*D*Inverse(V) depends upon V.Condition().

member.summary: Gets the absolute value of determinant of the square matrix for which the EVD was computed.

member.summary: Gets the effective numerical matrix rank.
member.value: The number of non-negligible singular values.

member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the matrix is full rank or not.
member.value: true if the matrix is full rank; otherwise false.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex32.Factorization.LU

summary.para: A class which encapsulates the functionality of an LU factorization.
For a matrix A, the LU factorization is a pair of lower triangular matrix L and upper triangular matrix U so that A = L*U.
In the Math.NET implementation we also store a set of pivot elements for increased numerical stability. The pivot elements encode a permutation matrix P such that P*A = L*U.

member.remarks: The computation of the LU factorization is done at construction time.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex32.Factorization.LU.Determinant
member.summary: Gets the determinant of the matrix for which the LU factorization was computed.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex32.Factorization.QR

summary.para: A class which encapsulates the functionality of the QR decomposition.

Any real square matrix A (m x n) may be decomposed as A = QR where Q is an orthogonal matrix (its columns are orthogonal unit vectors meaning QTQ = I) and R is an upper triangular matrix (also called right triangular matrix).

member.remarks: The computation of the QR decomposition is done at construction time by Householder transformation. If a factorization is performed, the resulting Q matrix is an m x m matrix and the R matrix is an m x n matrix. If a factorization is performed, the resulting Q matrix is an m x n matrix and the R matrix is an n x n matrix.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex32.Factorization.QR.Determinant
member.summary: Gets the absolute determinant value of the matrix for which the QR matrix was computed.

member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the matrix is full rank or not.
member.value: true if the matrix is full rank; otherwise false.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex32.Factorization.UserCholesky

summary.para: A class which encapsulates the functionality of a Cholesky factorization for user matrices.
For a symmetric, positive definite matrix A, the Cholesky factorization is an lower triangular matrix L so that A = L*L'.

member.remarks: The computation of the Cholesky factorization is done at construction time. If the matrix is not symmetric or positive definite, the constructor will throw an exception.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex32.Factorization.UserEvd
member.summary: Eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a complex matrix.
member.remarks: If A is Hermitian, then A = V*D*V' where the eigenvalue matrix D is diagonal and the eigenvector matrix V is Hermitian. I.e. A = V*D*V' and V*VH=I. If A is not symmetric, then the eigenvalue matrix D is block diagonal with the real eigenvalues in 1-by-1 blocks and any complex eigenvalues, lambda + i*mu, in 2-by-2 blocks, [lambda, mu; -mu, lambda]. The columns of V represent the eigenvectors in the sense that A*V = V*D, i.e. A.Multiply(V) equals V.Multiply(D). The matrix V may be badly conditioned, or even singular, so the validity of the equation A = V*D*Inverse(V) depends upon V.Condition().

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex32.Solvers.BiCgStab
member.summary: A Bi-Conjugate Gradient stabilized iterative matrix solver.

remarks.para:
The Bi-Conjugate Gradient Stabilized (BiCGStab) solver is an 'improvement' of the standard Conjugate Gradient (CG) solver. Unlike the CG solver the BiCGStab can be used on non-symmetric matrices.
Note that much of the success of the solver depends on the selection of the proper preconditioner.

The Bi-CGSTAB algorithm was taken from:
Templates for the solution of linear systems: Building blocks for iterative methods
Richard Barrett, Michael Berry, Tony F. Chan, James Demmel, June M. Donato, Jack Dongarra, Victor Eijkhout, Roldan Pozo, Charles Romine and Henk van der Vorst
Url: http://www.netlib.org/templates/Templates.html
Algorithm is described in Chapter 2, section 2.3.8, page 27
The example code below provides an indication of the possible use of the solver.

member.summary: Calculates the true residual of the matrix equation Ax = b according to: residual = b - Ax
member.param: Instance of the A.

Instance of the b.

member.summary: Solves the matrix equation Ax = b, where A is the coefficient matrix, b is the solution vector and x is the unknown vector.
member.param: The coefficient , A.
The solution , b.
The result , x.
The iterator to use to control when to stop iterating.
The preconditioner to use for approximations.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex32.Solvers.CompositeSolver
member.summary: A composite matrix solver. The actual solver is made by a sequence of matrix solvers.

remarks.para:
Solver based on:
Faster PDE-based simulations using robust composite linear solvers
S. Bhowmicka, P. Raghavan a,*, L. McInnes b, B. Norris
Future Generation Computer Systems, Vol 20, 2004, pp 373387
Note that if an iterator is passed to this solver it will be used for all the sub-solvers.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex32.Solvers.GpBiCg
member.summary: A Generalized Product Bi-Conjugate Gradient iterative matrix solver.

remarks.para:
The Generalized Product Bi-Conjugate Gradient (GPBiCG) solver is an alternative version of the Bi-Conjugate Gradient stabilized (CG) solver. Unlike the CG solver the GPBiCG solver can be used on non-symmetric matrices.
Note that much of the success of the solver depends on the selection of the proper preconditioner.

The GPBiCG algorithm was taken from:
GPBiCG(m,l): A hybrid of BiCGSTAB and GPBiCG methods with efficiency and robustness
S. Fujino
Applied Numerical Mathematics, Volume 41, 2002, pp 107 - 117
The example code below provides an indication of the possible use of the solver.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex32.Solvers.ILUTPPreconditioner
member.summary: This class performs an Incomplete LU factorization with drop tolerance and partial pivoting. The drop tolerance indicates which additional entries will be dropped from the factorized LU matrices.
member.remarks:
The ILUTP-Mem algorithm was taken from:
ILUTP_Mem: a Space-Efficient Incomplete LU Preconditioner
Tzu-Yi Chen, Department of Mathematics and Computer Science,
Pomona College, Claremont CA 91711, USA
Published in:
Lecture Notes in Computer Science
Volume 3046 / 2004
pp. 20 - 28
Algorithm is described in Section 2, page 22

member.summary: The array containing the pivot values.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex32.Solvers.ILUTPPreconditioner.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the default settings.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex32.Solvers.ILUTPPreconditioner.#ctor(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the specified settings.
member.param: The amount of fill that is allowed in the matrix. The value is a fraction of the number of non-zero entries in the original matrix. Values should be positive.

The absolute drop tolerance which indicates below what absolute value an entry will be dropped from the matrix. A drop tolerance of 0.0 means that no values will be dropped. Values should always be positive.
The pivot tolerance which indicates at what level pivoting will take place. A value of 0.0 means that no pivoting will take place.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex32.Solvers.ILUTPPreconditioner.FillLevel
member.summary: Gets or sets the amount of fill that is allowed in the matrix. The value is a fraction of the number of non-zero entries in the original matrix. The standard value is 200.

remarks.para: Values should always be positive and can be higher than 1.0. A value lower than 1.0 means that the eventual preconditioner matrix will have fewer non-zero entries as the original matrix. A value higher than 1.0 means that the eventual preconditioner can have more non-zero values than the original matrix.
Note that any changes to the FillLevel after creating the preconditioner will invalidate the created preconditioner and will require a re-initialization of the preconditioner.

member.exception: Thrown if a negative value is provided.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex32.Solvers.ILUTPPreconditioner.DropTolerance
member.summary: Gets or sets the absolute drop tolerance which indicates below what absolute value an entry will be dropped from the matrix. The standard value is 0.0001.

remarks.para: The values should always be positive and can be larger than 1.0. A low value will keep more small numbers in the preconditioner matrix. A high value will remove more small numbers from the preconditioner matrix.
Note that any changes to the DropTolerance after creating the preconditioner will invalidate the created preconditioner and will require a re-initialization of the preconditioner.

member.exception: Thrown if a negative value is provided.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex32.Solvers.ILUTPPreconditioner.PivotTolerance
member.summary: Gets or sets the pivot tolerance which indicates at what level pivoting will take place. The standard value is 0.0 which means pivoting will never take place.

remarks.para: The pivot tolerance is used to calculate if pivoting is necessary. Pivoting will take place if any of the values in a row is bigger than the diagonal value of that row divided by the pivot tolerance, i.e. pivoting will take place if row(i,j) > row(i,i) / PivotTolerance for any j that is not equal to i.
Note that any changes to the PivotTolerance after creating the preconditioner will invalidate the created preconditioner and will require a re-initialization of the preconditioner.

member.exception: Thrown if a negative value is provided.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex32.Solvers.ILUTPPreconditioner.UpperTriangle
member.summary: Returns the upper triagonal matrix that was created during the LU decomposition.
member.remarks: This method is used for debugging purposes only and should normally not be used.
member.returns: A new matrix containing the upper triagonal elements.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex32.Solvers.ILUTPPreconditioner.LowerTriangle
member.summary: Returns the lower triagonal matrix that was created during the LU decomposition.
member.remarks: This method is used for debugging purposes only and should normally not be used.
member.returns: A new matrix containing the lower triagonal elements.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex32.Solvers.ILUTPPreconditioner.Pivots
member.summary: Returns the pivot array. This array is not needed for normal use because the preconditioner will return the solution vector values in the proper order.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Complex32.Solvers.MlkBiCgStab
member.summary: A Multiple-Lanczos Bi-Conjugate Gradient stabilized iterative matrix solver.

remarks.para: The Multiple-Lanczos Bi-Conjugate Gradient stabilized (ML(k)-BiCGStab) solver is an 'improvement' of the standard BiCgStab solver.

The algorithm was taken from:
ML(k)BiCGSTAB: A BiCGSTAB variant based on multiple Lanczos starting vectors
Man-Chung Yeung and Tony F. Chan
SIAM Journal of Scientific Computing
Volume 21, Number 4, pp. 1263 - 1290
The example code below provides an indication of the possible use of the solver.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Factorization.Cholesky`1

summary.para: A class which encapsulates the functionality of a Cholesky factorization.
For a symmetric, positive definite matrix A, the Cholesky factorization is an lower triangular matrix L so that A = L*L'.

member.remarks: The computation of the Cholesky factorization is done at construction time. If the matrix is not symmetric or positive definite, the constructor will throw an exception.
member.typeparam: Supported data types are double, single, , and .

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Factorization.Cholesky`1.Factor
member.summary: Gets the lower triangular form of the Cholesky matrix.

member.summary: Gets the determinant of the matrix for which the Cholesky matrix was computed.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Factorization.Cholesky`1.DeterminantLn
member.summary: Gets the log determinant of the matrix for which the Cholesky matrix was computed.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Factorization.Evd`1
member.summary: Eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a real matrix.
member.remarks: If A is symmetric, then A = V*D*V' where the eigenvalue matrix D is diagonal and the eigenvector matrix V is orthogonal. I.e. A = V*D*V' and V*VT=I. If A is not symmetric, then the eigenvalue matrix D is block diagonal with the real eigenvalues in 1-by-1 blocks and any complex eigenvalues, lambda + i*mu, in 2-by-2 blocks, [lambda, mu; -mu, lambda]. The columns of V represent the eigenvectors in the sense that A*V = V*D, i.e. A.Multiply(V) equals V.Multiply(D). The matrix V may be badly conditioned, or even singular, so the validity of the equation A = V*D*Inverse(V) depends upon V.Condition().
member.typeparam: Supported data types are double, single, , and .

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Factorization.Evd`1.IsSymmetric
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether matrix is symmetric or not

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Factorization.Evd`1.Determinant
member.summary: Gets the absolute value of determinant of the square matrix for which the EVD was computed.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Factorization.Evd`1.Rank
member.summary: Gets the effective numerical matrix rank.
member.value: The number of non-negligible singular values.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Factorization.Evd`1.IsFullRank
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the matrix is full rank or not.
member.value: true if the matrix is full rank; otherwise false.

member.summary: Gets or sets eigenvectors.

member.summary: Gets or sets the block diagonal eigenvalue matrix.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Factorization.GramSchmidt`1

summary.para: A class which encapsulates the functionality of the QR decomposition Modified Gram-Schmidt Orthogonalization.
Any real square matrix A may be decomposed as A = QR where Q is an orthogonal mxn matrix and R is an nxn upper triangular matrix.

member.remarks: The computation of the QR decomposition is done at construction time by modified Gram-Schmidt Orthogonalization.
member.typeparam: Supported data types are double, single, , and .

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Factorization.LU`1

summary.para: A class which encapsulates the functionality of an LU factorization.
For a matrix A, the LU factorization is a pair of lower triangular matrix L and upper triangular matrix U so that A = L*U.
In the Math.NET implementation we also store a set of pivot elements for increased numerical stability. The pivot elements encode a permutation matrix P such that P*A = L*U.

member.remarks: The computation of the LU factorization is done at construction time.
member.typeparam: Supported data types are double, single, , and .

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Factorization.LU`1.L
member.summary: Gets the lower triangular factor.

member.summary: Gets the upper triangular factor.

member.summary: Gets the permutation applied to LU factorization.

member.summary: Gets the determinant of the matrix for which the LU factorization was computed.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Factorization.QR`1

summary.para: A class which encapsulates the functionality of the QR decomposition.

Any real square matrix A (m x n) may be decomposed as A = QR where Q is an orthogonal matrix (its columns are orthogonal unit vectors meaning QTQ = I) and R is an upper triangular matrix (also called right triangular matrix).

member.remarks: The computation of the QR decomposition is done at construction time by Householder transformation. If a factorization is performed, the resulting Q matrix is an m x m matrix and the R matrix is an m x n matrix. If a factorization is performed, the resulting Q matrix is an m x n matrix and the R matrix is an n x n matrix.
member.typeparam: Supported data types are double, single, , and .

member.summary: Gets or sets orthogonal Q matrix

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Solvers.IPreconditioner`1
member.summary: The base interface for preconditioner classes.

remarks.para: Preconditioners are used by iterative solvers to improve the convergence speed of the solving process. Increase in convergence speed is related to the number of iterations necessary to get a converged solution. So while in general the use of a preconditioner means that the iterative solver will perform fewer iterations it does not guarantee that the actual solution time decreases given that some preconditioners can be expensive to setup and run.
Note that in general changes to the matrix will invalidate the preconditioner if the changes occur after creating the preconditioner.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Storage.SparseCompressedRowMatrixStorage`1.RowPointers
member.summary: The array containing the row indices of the existing rows. Element "i" of the array gives the index of the element in the array that is first non-zero element in a row "i". The last value is equal to ValueCount, so that the number of non-zero entries in row "i" is always given by RowPointers[i+i] - RowPointers[i]. This array thus has length RowCount+1.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Storage.SparseCompressedRowMatrixStorage`1.ColumnIndices
member.summary: An array containing the column indices of the non-zero values. Element "j" of the array is the number of the column in matrix that contains the j-th value in the array.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Storage.SparseCompressedRowMatrixStorage`1.Values
member.summary: Array that contains the non-zero elements of matrix. Values of the non-zero elements of matrix are mapped into the values array using the row-major storage mapping described in a compressed sparse row (CSR) format.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Optimization.LineSearch.WeakWolfeLineSearch
member.summary:
Search for a step size alpha that satisfies the weak Wolfe conditions. The weak Wolfe Conditions are i) Armijo Rule: f(x_k + alpha_k p_k) <= f(x_k) + c1 alpha_k p_k^T g(x_k) ii) Curvature Condition: p_k^T g(x_k + alpha_k p_k) >= c2 p_k^T g(x_k) where g(x) is the gradient of f(x), 0 < c1 < c2 < 1.
Implementation is based on http://www.math.washington.edu/~burke/crs/408/lectures/L9-weak-Wolfe.pdf
references: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wolfe_conditions http://www.math.washington.edu/~burke/crs/408/lectures/L9-weak-Wolfe.pdf

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Optimization.LineSearch.WolfeLineSearch.FindConformingStep(MathNet.Numerics.Optimization.IObjectiveFunctionEvaluation,MathNet.Numerics.LinearAlgebra.Vector{System.Double},System.Double)
member.summary: Implemented following http://www.math.washington.edu/~burke/crs/408/lectures/L9-weak-Wolfe.pdf
member.param: The objective function being optimized, evaluated at the starting point of the search
Search direction
Initial size of the step in the search direction

Search direction

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Optimization.ObjectiveFunctions.ForwardDifferenceGradientObjectiveFunction
member.summary:
Adapts an objective function with only value implemented to provide a gradient as well. Gradient calculation is done using the finite difference method, specifically forward differences.
For each gradient computed, the algorithm requires an additional number of function evaluations equal to the functions's number of input parameters.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the Permutation class.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Permutation.FromInversions(System.Int32[])

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Polynomial.Degree
member.summary: Degree of the polynomial, i.e. the largest monomial exponent. For example, the degree of y=x^2+x^5 is 5, for y=3 it is 0. The null-polynomial returns degree -1 because the correct degree, negative infinity, cannot be represented by integers.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Polynomial.#ctor(System.Int32)

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Precision
member.summary: Utilities for working with floating point numbers.

remarks.para:
Useful links:
http://docs.sun.com/source/806-3568/ncg_goldberg.html#689 - What every computer scientist should know about floating-point arithmetic
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_epsilon - Gives the definition of machine epsilon

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.CompareTo(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Compares two doubles and determines which double is bigger. a < b -> -1; a ~= b (almost equal according to parameter) -> 0; a > b -> +1.
member.param: The first value.
The second value.
The absolute accuracy required for being almost equal.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.CompareTo(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Compares two doubles and determines which double is bigger. a < b -> -1; a ~= b (almost equal according to parameter) -> 0; a > b -> +1.
member.param: The first value.
The second value.
The number of decimal places on which the values must be compared. Must be 1 or larger.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.CompareToRelative(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Compares two doubles and determines which double is bigger. a < b -> -1; a ~= b (almost equal according to parameter) -> 0; a > b -> +1.
member.param: The first value.
The second value.
The relative accuracy required for being almost equal.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.CompareToRelative(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Compares two doubles and determines which double is bigger. a < b -> -1; a ~= b (almost equal according to parameter) -> 0; a > b -> +1.
member.param: The first value.
The second value.
The number of decimal places on which the values must be compared. Must be 1 or larger.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.CompareToNumbersBetween(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int64)
member.summary: Compares two doubles and determines which double is bigger. a < b -> -1; a ~= b (almost equal according to parameter) -> 0; a > b -> +1.
member.param: The first value.
The second value.
The maximum error in terms of Units in Last Place (ulps), i.e. the maximum number of decimals that may be different. Must be 1 or larger.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.IsLarger(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Compares two doubles and determines if the first value is larger than the second value to within the specified number of decimal places or not.

remarks.para: The values are equal if the difference between the two numbers is smaller than 10^(-numberOfDecimalPlaces). We divide by two so that we have half the range on each side of the numbers, e.g. if == 2, then 0.01 will equal between 0.005 and 0.015, but not 0.02 and not 0.00

member.param: The first value.
The second value.
The number of decimal places.
member.returns: true if the first value is larger than the second value; otherwise false.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.IsFinite(System.Double)
member.summary: Checks if a given double values is finite, i.e. neither NaN nor inifnity
member.param: The value to be checked fo finitenes.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.DoubleWidth
member.summary: The number of binary digits used to represent the binary number for a double precision floating point value. i.e. there are this many digits used to represent the actual number, where in a number as: 0.134556 * 10^5 the digits are 0.134556 and the exponent is 5.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.SingleWidth
member.summary: The number of binary digits used to represent the binary number for a single precision floating point value. i.e. there are this many digits used to represent the actual number, where in a number as: 0.134556 * 10^5 the digits are 0.134556 and the exponent is 5.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.DoublePrecision
member.summary: Standard epsilon, the maximum relative precision of IEEE 754 double-precision floating numbers (64 bit). According to the definition of Prof. Demmel and used in LAPACK and Scilab.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.PositiveDoublePrecision
member.summary: Standard epsilon, the maximum relative precision of IEEE 754 double-precision floating numbers (64 bit). According to the definition of Prof. Higham and used in the ISO C standard and MATLAB.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.SinglePrecision
member.summary: Standard epsilon, the maximum relative precision of IEEE 754 single-precision floating numbers (32 bit). According to the definition of Prof. Demmel and used in LAPACK and Scilab.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.PositiveSinglePrecision
member.summary: Standard epsilon, the maximum relative precision of IEEE 754 single-precision floating numbers (32 bit). According to the definition of Prof. Higham and used in the ISO C standard and MATLAB.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.MachineEpsilon
member.summary: Actual double precision machine epsilon, the smallest number that can be subtracted from 1, yielding a results different than 1. This is also known as unit roundoff error. According to the definition of Prof. Demmel. On a standard machine this is equivalent to `DoublePrecision`.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.PositiveMachineEpsilon
member.summary: Actual double precision machine epsilon, the smallest number that can be added to 1, yielding a results different than 1. This is also known as unit roundoff error. According to the definition of Prof. Higham. On a standard machine this is equivalent to `PositiveDoublePrecision`.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.DoubleDecimalPlaces
member.summary: The number of significant decimal places of double-precision floating numbers (64 bit).

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.SingleDecimalPlaces
member.summary: The number of significant decimal places of single-precision floating numbers (32 bit).

member.summary: Returns the magnitude of the number.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.ScaleUnitMagnitude(System.Double)

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.AsDirectionalInt64(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns a 'directional' long value. This is a long value which acts the same as a double, e.g. a negative double value will return a negative double value starting at 0 and going more negative as the double value gets more negative.
member.param: The input double value.
member.returns: A long value which is roughly the equivalent of the double value.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.AsDirectionalInt32(System.Single)
member.summary: Returns a 'directional' int value. This is a int value which acts the same as a float, e.g. a negative float value will return a negative int value starting at 0 and going more negative as the float value gets more negative.
member.param: The input float value.
member.returns: An int value which is roughly the equivalent of the double value.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.Increment(System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Increments a floating point number to the next bigger number representable by the data type.
member.param: The value which needs to be incremented.
How many times the number should be incremented.
member.remarks: The incrementation step length depends on the provided value. Increment(double.MaxValue) will return positive infinity.
member.returns: The next larger floating point value.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.Decrement(System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Decrements a floating point number to the next smaller number representable by the data type.
member.param: The value which should be decremented.
How many times the number should be decremented.
member.remarks: The decrementation step length depends on the provided value. Decrement(double.MinValue) will return negative infinity.
member.returns: The next smaller floating point value.

member.summary: Evaluates the count of numbers between two double numbers

The second parameter.
member.remarks: The second number is included in the number, thus two equal numbers evaluate to zero and two neighbor numbers evaluate to one. Therefore, what is returned is actually the count of numbers between plus 1.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.AlmostEqualNorm(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Compares two doubles and determines if they are equal to within the specified number of decimal places or not, using the number of decimal places as an absolute measure.

remarks.para: The values are equal if the difference between the two numbers is smaller than 0.5e-decimalPlaces. We divide by two so that we have half the range on each side of the numbers, e.g. if == 2, then 0.01 will equal between 0.005 and 0.015, but not 0.02 and not 0.00

member.param: The norm of the first value (can be negative).
The norm of the second value (can be negative).
The norm of the difference of the two values (can be negative).
The number of decimal places.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.AlmostEqualNorm``1(``0,``0,System.Int32)

member.param: The norm of the first value (can be negative).
The norm of the second value (can be negative).
The norm of the difference of the two values (can be negative).
The number of decimal places.
member.exception: Thrown if is smaller than zero.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.AlmostEqualNumbersBetween(System.Double,System.Double,System.Int64)
member.summary: Compares two doubles and determines if they are equal to within the tolerance or not. Equality comparison is based on the binary representation.

remarks.para: Determines the 'number' of floating point numbers between two values (i.e. the number of discrete steps between the two numbers) and then checks if that is within the specified tolerance. So if a tolerance of 1 is passed then the result will be true only if the two numbers have the same binary representation OR if they are two adjacent numbers that only differ by one step.

The comparison method used is explained in http://www.cygnus-software.com/papers/comparingfloats/comparingfloats.htm . The article at http://www.extremeoptimization.com/resources/Articles/FPDotNetConceptsAndFormats.aspx explains how to transform the C code to .NET enabled code without using pointers and unsafe code.

member.param: The first value.
The second value.
The maximum number of floating point values between the two values. Must be 1 or larger.
member.exception: Thrown if is smaller than one.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Precision.AlmostEqualNumbersBetween(System.Single,System.Single,System.Int32)
member.summary: Compares two floats and determines if they are equal to within the tolerance or not. Equality comparison is based on the binary representation.
member.param: The first value.
The second value.
The maximum number of floating point values between the two values. Must be 1 or larger.
member.exception: Thrown if is smaller than one.

member.summary: Computes the LUP factorization of A. P*A = L*U.
member.param: An by matrix. The matrix is overwritten with the the LU factorization on exit. The lower triangular factor L is stored in under the diagonal of (the diagonal is always 1.0 for the L factor). The upper triangular factor U is stored on and above the diagonal of .

On exit, it contains the pivot indices. The size of the array must be .
member.remarks: This is equivalent to the GETRF LAPACK routine.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Random.RandomSeed.Time
member.summary: Provides a time-dependent seed value, matching the default behavior of System.Random. WARNING: There is no randomness in this seed and quick repeated calls can cause the same seed value. Do not use for cryptography!

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Random.RandomSeed.Guid
member.summary: Provides a seed based on time and unique GUIDs. WARNING: There is only low randomness in this seed, but at least quick repeated calls will result in different seed values. Do not use for cryptography!

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Random.RandomSeed.Robust
member.summary: Provides a seed based on an internal random number generator (crypto if available), time and unique GUIDs. WARNING: There is only medium randomness in this seed, but quick repeated calls will result in different seed values. Do not use for cryptography!

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Random.Xoshiro256StarStar
member.summary: Xoshiro256** pseudo random number generator. A random number generator based on the class in the .NET library.
member.remarks:
This is xoshiro256** 1.0, our all-purpose, rock-solid generator. It has excellent(sub-ns) speed, a state space(256 bits) that is large enough for any parallel application, and it passes all tests we are aware of.
For generating just floating-point numbers, xoshiro256+ is even faster.
The state must be seeded so that it is not everywhere zero.If you have a 64-bit seed, we suggest to seed a splitmix64 generator and use its output to fill s.
For further details see: David Blackman & Sebastiano Vigna (2018), "Scrambled Linear Pseudorandom Number Generators". https://arxiv.org/abs/1805.01407

remarks.para: This implementation of the computation of the Exponential Integral function follows the derivation in "Handbook of Mathematical Functions, Applied Mathematics Series, Volume 55", Abramowitz, M., and Stegun, I.A. 1964, reprinted 1968 by Dover Publications, New York), Chapters 6, 7, and 26. AND "Advanced mathematical methods for scientists and engineers", Bender, Carl M.; Steven A. Orszag (1978). page 253
for x > 1 uses continued fraction approach that is often used to compute incomplete gamma. for 0 < x <= 1 uses Taylor series expansion
Our unit tests suggest that the accuracy of the Exponential Integral function is correct up to 13 floating point digits.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.Factorial(System.Int32)
member.summary: Computes the factorial function x -> x! of an integer number > 0. The function can represent all number up to 22! exactly, all numbers up to 170! using a double representation. All larger values will overflow.
member.returns: A value value! for value > 0
member.remarks: If you need to multiply or divide various such factorials, consider using the logarithmic version instead so you can add instead of multiply and subtract instead of divide, and then exponentiate the result using . This will also circumvent the problem that factorials become very large even for small parameters.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.GammaLn(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the logarithm of the Gamma function.
member.param: The argument of the gamma function.
member.returns: The logarithm of the gamma function.

remarks.para: This implementation of the computation of the gamma and logarithm of the gamma function follows the derivation in "An Analysis Of The Lanczos Gamma Approximation", Glendon Ralph Pugh, 2004. We use the implementation listed on p. 116 which achieves an accuracy of 16 floating point digits. Although 16 digit accuracy should be sufficient for double values, improving accuracy is possible (see p. 126 in Pugh).
Our unit tests suggest that the accuracy of the Gamma function is correct up to 14 floating point digits.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.Gamma(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the Gamma function.
member.param: The argument of the gamma function.
member.returns: The logarithm of the gamma function.

remarks.para: This implementation of the computation of the gamma and logarithm of the gamma function follows the derivation in "An Analysis Of The Lanczos Gamma Approximation", Glendon Ralph Pugh, 2004. We use the implementation listed on p. 116 which should achieve an accuracy of 16 floating point digits. Although 16 digit accuracy should be sufficient for double values, improving accuracy is possible (see p. 126 in Pugh).
Our unit tests suggest that the accuracy of the Gamma function is correct up to 13 floating point digits.

The lower integral limit.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.GammaLowerRegularizedInv(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the inverse P^(-1) of the regularized lower incomplete gamma function P(a,x) = 1/Gamma(a) * int(exp(-t)t^(a-1),t=0..x) for real a > 0, x > 0, such that P^(-1)(a,P(a,x)) == x.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.DiGamma(System.Double)
member.summary: Computes the Digamma function which is mathematically defined as the derivative of the logarithm of the gamma function. This implementation is based on Jose Bernardo Algorithm AS 103: Psi ( Digamma ) Function, Applied Statistics, Volume 25, Number 3, 1976, pages 315-317. Using the modifications as in Tom Minka's lightspeed toolbox.
member.param: The argument of the digamma function.
member.returns: The value of the DiGamma function at .

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.DiGammaInv(System.Double)

summary.para: Computes the inverse Digamma function: this is the inverse of the logarithm of the gamma function. This function will only return solutions that are positive.
This implementation is based on the bisection method.

member.param: The argument of the inverse digamma function.
member.returns: The positive solution to the inverse DiGamma function at .

member.summary:
Returns the Hankel function of the first kind.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.HankelH1Scaled(System.Double,System.Numerics.Complex)
member.summary:

ScaledHankelH1(n, z) is given by Exp(-z * j) * HankelH1(n, z) where j = Sqrt(-1).
member.param: The order of the Hankel function.
The value to compute the Hankel function of.
member.returns: The exponentially scaled Hankel function of the first kind.

member.param: The order of generalized Marcum Q-function. Range: 110000

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.MarcumQ(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32@)

References: A. Gil, J. Segura and N.M. Temme. Efficient and accurate algorithms for the computation and inversion of the incomplete gamma function ratios. SIAM J Sci Comput. (2012) 34(6), A2965-A2981
member.param: The order of generalized Marcum Q-function. Range: 110000
The value to compute the Marcum Q-function of. Range: 0a10000
The value to compute the Marcum Q-function of. Range: 0b10000

Error flag
0: Computation succesful.
1: Underflow problems. The function value is set to one.
2: Any of the arguments of the function is out of range.The function value is set to zero.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.BesselI0A
member.summary:
Chebyshev coefficients for exp(-x) I0(x) in the interval [0, 8].
lim(x->0){ exp(-x) I0(x) } = 1.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.BesselI0B
member.summary:
Chebyshev coefficients for exp(-x) sqrt(x) I0(x) in the inverted interval [8, infinity].
lim(x->inf){ exp(-x) sqrt(x) I0(x) } = 1/sqrt(2pi).

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.BesselI1A
member.summary:
Chebyshev coefficients for exp(-x) I1(x) / x in the interval [0, 8].
lim(x->0){ exp(-x) I1(x) / x } = 1/2.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.BesselI1B
member.summary:
Chebyshev coefficients for exp(-x) sqrt(x) I1(x) in the inverted interval [8, infinity].
lim(x->inf){ exp(-x) sqrt(x) I1(x) } = 1/sqrt(2pi).

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.BesselK0A
member.summary:
Chebyshev coefficients for K0(x) + log(x/2) I0(x) in the interval [0, 2]. The odd order coefficients are all zero; only the even order coefficients are listed.
lim(x->0){ K0(x) + log(x/2) I0(x) } = -EUL.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.BesselK0B
member.summary:
Chebyshev coefficients for exp(x) sqrt(x) K0(x) in the inverted interval [2, infinity].
lim(x->inf){ exp(x) sqrt(x) K0(x) } = sqrt(pi/2).

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.BesselK1A
member.summary:
Chebyshev coefficients for x(K1(x) - log(x/2) I1(x)) in the interval [0, 2].
lim(x->0){ x(K1(x) - log(x/2) I1(x)) } = 1.

member.name: F:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.BesselK1B
member.summary:
Chebyshev coefficients for exp(x) sqrt(x) K1(x) in the interval [2, infinity].
lim(x->inf){ exp(x) sqrt(x) K1(x) } = sqrt(pi/2).

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.BesselI0(System.Double)
member.summary:
Returns the modified Bessel function of first kind, order 0 of the argument.
The function is defined as i0(x) = j0( ix ).
The range is partitioned into the two intervals [0, 8] and (8, infinity). Chebyshev polynomial expansions are employed in each interval.

member.summary:
Returns the modified Bessel function of the second kind of order 1 of the argument.
The range is partitioned into the two intervals [0, 2] and (2, infinity). Chebyshev polynomial expansions are employed in each interval.
member.param: The value to compute the Bessel function of.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.BesselK1e(System.Double)
member.summary:
Returns the exponentially scaled modified Bessel function of the second kind of order 1 of the argument.
k1e(x) = exp(x) * k1(x).
member.param: The value to compute the Bessel function of.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.StruveL0(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the modified Struve function of order 0.
member.param: The value to compute the function of.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.StruveL1(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the modified Struve function of order 1.
member.param: The value to compute the function of.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.BesselI0MStruveL0(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the difference between the Bessel I0 and Struve L0 functions.
member.param: The value to compute the function of.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.BesselI1MStruveL1(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the difference between the Bessel I1 and Struve L1 functions.
member.param: The value to compute the function of.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.SphericalBesselJ(System.Double,System.Numerics.Complex)
member.summary:
Returns the spherical Bessel function of the first kind.
SphericalBesselJ(n, z) is given by Sqrt(pi/2) / Sqrt(z) * BesselJ(n + 1/2, z).
member.param: The order of the spherical Bessel function.
The value to compute the spherical Bessel function of.
member.returns: The spherical Bessel function of the first kind.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.SpecialFunctions.SphericalBesselJ(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary:

The value to compute the spherical Bessel function of.

member.returns: The spherical Bessel function of the second kind.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Evaluate
member.summary: Evaluation functions, useful for function approximation.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Evaluate.ChebyshevA(System.Double[],System.Double)
member.summary:
Evaluates the series of Chebyshev polynomials Ti at argument x/2. The series is given by
N-1 - ' y = > coef[i] T (x/2) - i i=0
Coefficients are stored in reverse order, i.e. the zero order term is last in the array. Note N is the number of coefficients, not the order.
If coefficients are for the interval a to b, x must have been transformed to x -> 2(2x - b - a)/(b-a) before entering the routine. This maps x from (a, b) to (-1, 1), over which the Chebyshev polynomials are defined.
If the coefficients are for the inverted interval, in which (a, b) is mapped to (1/b, 1/a), the transformation required is x -> 2(2ab/x - b - a)/(b-a). If b is infinity, this becomes x -> 4a/x - 1.
SPEED:
Taking advantage of the recurrence properties of the Chebyshev polynomials, the routine requires one more addition per loop than evaluating a nested polynomial of the same degree.
member.param: The coefficients of the polynomial.
Argument to the polynomial.
member.remarks:
Reference: https://bpm2.svn.codeplex.com/svn/Common.Numeric/Arithmetic.cs
Marked as Deprecated in http://people.apache.org/~isabel/mahout_site/mahout-matrix/apidocs/org/apache/mahout/jet/math/Arithmetic.html

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Evaluate.ChebyshevSum(System.Int32,System.Double[],System.Double)
member.summary: Summation of Chebyshev polynomials, using the Clenshaw method with Reinsch modification.
member.param: The no. of terms in the sequence.
The coefficients of the Chebyshev series, length n+1.
The value at which the series is to be evaluated.
member.remarks: ORIGINAL AUTHOR: Dr. Allan J. MacLeod; Dept. of Mathematics and Statistics, University of Paisley; High St., PAISLEY, SCOTLAND REFERENCES: "An error analysis of the modified Clenshaw method for evaluating Chebyshev and Fourier series" J. Oliver, J.I.M.A., vol. 20, 1977, pp379-391

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.TestFunctions.Rosenbrock(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Valley-shaped Rosenbrock function for 2 dimensions: (x,y) -> (1-x)^2 + 100*(y-x^2)^2. This function has a global minimum at (1,1) with f(1,1) = 0. Common range: [-5,10] or [-2.048,2.048].
member.remarks: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rosenbrock_function http://www.sfu.ca/~ssurjano/rosen.html

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.TestFunctions.Rosenbrock(System.Double[])
member.summary: Valley-shaped Rosenbrock function for 2 or more dimensions. This function have a global minimum of all ones and, for 8 > N > 3, a local minimum at (-1,1,...,1).
member.remarks: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rosenbrock_function http://www.sfu.ca/~ssurjano/rosen.html

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.TestFunctions.Himmelblau(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Himmelblau, a multi-modal function: (x,y) -> (x^2+y-11)^2 + (x+y^2-7)^2 This function has 4 global minima with f(x,y) = 0. Common range: [-6,6]. Named after David Mautner Himmelblau
member.remarks: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Himmelblau%27s_function

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.TestFunctions.Rastrigin(System.Double[])
member.summary: Rastrigin, a highly multi-modal function with many local minima. Global minimum of all zeros with f(0) = 0. Common range: [-5.12,5.12].
member.remarks: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rastrigin_function http://www.sfu.ca/~ssurjano/rastr.html

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.TestFunctions.DropWave(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Drop-Wave, a multi-modal and highly complex function with many local minima. Global minimum of all zeros with f(0) = -1. Common range: [-5.12,5.12].
member.remarks: http://www.sfu.ca/~ssurjano/drop.html

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.TestFunctions.Ackley(System.Double[])
member.summary: Ackley, a function with many local minima. It is nearly flat in outer regions but has a large hole at the center. Global minimum of all zeros with f(0) = 0. Common range: [-32.768, 32.768].
member.remarks: http://www.sfu.ca/~ssurjano/ackley.html

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.TestFunctions.Bohachevsky1(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Bowl-shaped first Bohachevsky function. Global minimum of all zeros with f(0,0) = 0. Common range: [-100, 100]
member.remarks: http://www.sfu.ca/~ssurjano/boha.html

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.TestFunctions.Matyas(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Plate-shaped Matyas function. Global minimum of all zeros with f(0,0) = 0. Common range: [-10, 10].
member.remarks: http://www.sfu.ca/~ssurjano/matya.html

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.TestFunctions.SixHumpCamel(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Valley-shaped six-hump camel back function. Two global minima and four local minima. Global minima with f(x) ) -1.0316 at (0.0898,-0.7126) and (-0.0898,0.7126). Common range: x in [-3,3], y in [-2,2].
member.remarks: http://www.sfu.ca/~ssurjano/camel6.html

member.summary: Estimates the p-Percentile value from the unsorted data array. If a non-integer Percentile is needed, use Quantile instead. Approximately median-unbiased regardless of the sample distribution (R8). WARNING: Works inplace and can thus causes the data array to be reordered.

Percentile selector, between 0 and 100 (inclusive).

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.ArrayStatistics.FiveNumberSummaryInplace(System.Double[])
member.summary: Estimates {min, lower-quantile, median, upper-quantile, max} from the unsorted data array. Approximately median-unbiased regardless of the sample distribution (R8). WARNING: Works inplace and can thus causes the data array to be reordered.
member.param: Sample array, no sorting is assumed. Will be reordered.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.ArrayStatistics.QuantileInplace(System.Double[],System.Double)
member.summary: Estimates the tau-th quantile from the unsorted data array. The tau-th quantile is the data value where the cumulative distribution function crosses tau. Approximately median-unbiased regardless of the sample distribution (R8). WARNING: Works inplace and can thus causes the data array to be reordered.
member.param: Sample array, no sorting is assumed. Will be reordered.
Quantile selector, between 0.0 and 1.0 (inclusive).
member.remarks: R-8, SciPy-(1/3,1/3): Linear interpolation of the approximate medians for order statistics. When tau < (2/3) / (N + 1/3), use x1. When tau >= (N - 1/3) / (N + 1/3), use xN.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.ArrayStatistics.QuantileCustomInplace(System.Double[],System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Estimates the tau-th quantile from the unsorted data array. The tau-th quantile is the data value where the cumulative distribution function crosses tau. The quantile definition can be specified by 4 parameters a, b, c and d, consistent with Mathematica. WARNING: Works inplace and can thus causes the data array to be reordered.
member.param: Sample array, no sorting is assumed. Will be reordered.
Quantile selector, between 0.0 and 1.0 (inclusive)
a-parameter
b-parameter
c-parameter
d-parameter

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.ArrayStatistics.QuantileCustomInplace(System.Double[],System.Double,MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.QuantileDefinition)
member.summary: Estimates the tau-th quantile from the unsorted data array. The tau-th quantile is the data value where the cumulative distribution function crosses tau. The quantile definition can be specified to be compatible with an existing system. WARNING: Works inplace and can thus causes the data array to be reordered.
member.param: Sample array, no sorting is assumed. Will be reordered.
Quantile selector, between 0.0 and 1.0 (inclusive)
Quantile definition, to choose what product/definition it should be consistent with

member.summary: Estimates the unbiased population standard deviation from the provided samples as unsorted array. On a dataset of size N will use an N-1 normalizer (Bessel's correction). Returns NaN if data has less than two entries or if any entry is NaN.
member.param: Sample array, no sorting is assumed.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.ArrayStatistics.PopulationStandardDeviation(System.Single[])
member.summary: Evaluates the population standard deviation from the full population provided as unsorted array. On a dataset of size N will use an N normalizer and would thus be biased if applied to a subset. Returns NaN if data is empty or if any entry is NaN.
member.param: Sample array, no sorting is assumed.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.ArrayStatistics.MeanVariance(System.Single[])
member.summary: Estimates the arithmetic sample mean and the unbiased population variance from the provided samples as unsorted array. On a dataset of size N will use an N-1 normalizer (Bessel's correction). Returns NaN for mean if data is empty or any entry is NaN and NaN for variance if data has less than two entries or if any entry is NaN.
member.param: Sample array, no sorting is assumed.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.ArrayStatistics.MeanStandardDeviation(System.Single[])
member.summary: Estimates the arithmetic sample mean and the unbiased population standard deviation from the provided samples as unsorted array. On a dataset of size N will use an N-1 normalizer (Bessel's correction). Returns NaN for mean if data is empty or any entry is NaN and NaN for standard deviation if data has less than two entries or if any entry is NaN.
member.param: Sample array, no sorting is assumed.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.ArrayStatistics.Covariance(System.Single[],System.Single[])
member.summary: Estimates the unbiased population covariance from the provided two sample arrays. On a dataset of size N will use an N-1 normalizer (Bessel's correction). Returns NaN if data has less than two entries or if any entry is NaN.
member.param: First sample array.
Second sample array.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.ArrayStatistics.PopulationCovariance(System.Single[],System.Single[])
member.summary: Evaluates the population covariance from the full population provided as two arrays. On a dataset of size N will use an N normalizer and would thus be biased if applied to a subset. Returns NaN if data is empty or if any entry is NaN.
member.param: First population array.
Second population array.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.ArrayStatistics.RootMeanSquare(System.Single[])
member.summary: Estimates the root mean square (RMS) also known as quadratic mean from the unsorted data array. Returns NaN if data is empty or any entry is NaN.
member.param: Sample array, no sorting is assumed.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.ArrayStatistics.OrderStatisticInplace(System.Single[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the order statistic (order 1..N) from the unsorted data array. WARNING: Works inplace and can thus causes the data array to be reordered.
member.param: Sample array, no sorting is assumed. Will be reordered.
One-based order of the statistic, must be between 1 and N (inclusive).

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.ArrayStatistics.MedianInplace(System.Single[])
member.summary: Estimates the median value from the unsorted data array. WARNING: Works inplace and can thus causes the data array to be reordered.
member.param: Sample array, no sorting is assumed. Will be reordered.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.ArrayStatistics.PercentileInplace(System.Single[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Estimates the p-Percentile value from the unsorted data array. If a non-integer Percentile is needed, use Quantile instead. Approximately median-unbiased regardless of the sample distribution (R8). WARNING: Works inplace and can thus causes the data array to be reordered.
member.param: Sample array, no sorting is assumed. Will be reordered.
Percentile selector, between 0 and 100 (inclusive).

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.ArrayStatistics.LowerQuartileInplace(System.Single[])
member.summary: Estimates the first quartile value from the unsorted data array. Approximately median-unbiased regardless of the sample distribution (R8). WARNING: Works inplace and can thus causes the data array to be reordered.
member.param: Sample array, no sorting is assumed. Will be reordered.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.ArrayStatistics.UpperQuartileInplace(System.Single[])
member.summary: Estimates the third quartile value from the unsorted data array. Approximately median-unbiased regardless of the sample distribution (R8). WARNING: Works inplace and can thus causes the data array to be reordered.
member.param: Sample array, no sorting is assumed. Will be reordered.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.ArrayStatistics.InterquartileRangeInplace(System.Single[])
member.summary: Estimates the inter-quartile range from the unsorted data array. Approximately median-unbiased regardless of the sample distribution (R8). WARNING: Works inplace and can thus causes the data array to be reordered.
member.param: Sample array, no sorting is assumed. Will be reordered.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.ArrayStatistics.FiveNumberSummaryInplace(System.Single[])
member.summary: Estimates {min, lower-quantile, median, upper-quantile, max} from the unsorted data array. Approximately median-unbiased regardless of the sample distribution (R8). WARNING: Works inplace and can thus causes the data array to be reordered.
member.param: Sample array, no sorting is assumed. Will be reordered.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.ArrayStatistics.QuantileInplace(System.Single[],System.Double)
member.summary: Estimates the tau-th quantile from the unsorted data array. The tau-th quantile is the data value where the cumulative distribution function crosses tau. Approximately median-unbiased regardless of the sample distribution (R8). WARNING: Works inplace and can thus causes the data array to be reordered.
member.param: Sample array, no sorting is assumed. Will be reordered.
Quantile selector, between 0.0 and 1.0 (inclusive).
member.remarks: R-8, SciPy-(1/3,1/3): Linear interpolation of the approximate medians for order statistics. When tau < (2/3) / (N + 1/3), use x1. When tau >= (N - 1/3) / (N + 1/3), use xN.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.ArrayStatistics.QuantileCustomInplace(System.Single[],System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Estimates the tau-th quantile from the unsorted data array. The tau-th quantile is the data value where the cumulative distribution function crosses tau. The quantile definition can be specified by 4 parameters a, b, c and d, consistent with Mathematica. WARNING: Works inplace and can thus causes the data array to be reordered.
member.param: Sample array, no sorting is assumed. Will be reordered.
Quantile selector, between 0.0 and 1.0 (inclusive)
a-parameter
b-parameter
c-parameter
d-parameter

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.ArrayStatistics.QuantileCustomInplace(System.Single[],System.Double,MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.QuantileDefinition)
member.summary: Estimates the tau-th quantile from the unsorted data array. The tau-th quantile is the data value where the cumulative distribution function crosses tau. The quantile definition can be specified to be compatible with an existing system. WARNING: Works inplace and can thus causes the data array to be reordered.
member.param: Sample array, no sorting is assumed. Will be reordered.
Quantile selector, between 0.0 and 1.0 (inclusive)
Quantile definition, to choose what product/definition it should be consistent with

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.ArrayStatistics.RanksInplace(System.Single[],MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.RankDefinition)

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.DescriptiveStatistics
member.summary: Computes the basic statistics of data set. The class meets the NIST standard of accuracy for mean, variance, and standard deviation (the only statistics they provide exact values for) and exceeds them in increased accuracy mode. Recommendation: consider to use RunningStatistics instead.
member.remarks: This type declares a DataContract for out of the box ephemeral serialization with engines like DataContractSerializer, Protocol Buffers and FsPickler, but does not guarantee any compatibility between versions. It is not recommended to rely on this mechanism for durable persistence.

member.name: M:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.DescriptiveStatistics.#ctor(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Double},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.
member.param: The sample data.
If set to true, increased accuracy mode used. Increased accuracy mode uses types for internal calculations.
member.remarks: Don't use increased accuracy for data sets containing large values (in absolute value). This may cause the calculations to overflow.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.HybridMCGeneric`1
member.summary: The Hybrid (also called Hamiltonian) Monte Carlo produces samples from distribution P using a set of Hamiltonian equations to guide the sampling process. It uses the negative of the log density as a potential energy, and a randomly generated momentum to set up a Hamiltonian system, which is then used to sample the distribution. This can result in a faster convergence than the random walk Metropolis sampler ().
member.typeparam: The type of samples this sampler produces.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.GlobalProposalSampler`1
member.summary: A method which samples datapoints from a proposal distribution. The implementation of this sampler is stateless: no variables are saved between two calls to Sample. This proposal is different from in that it doesn't take any parameters; it samples random variables from the whole domain.
member.typeparam: The type of the datapoints.
member.returns: A sample from the proposal distribution.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.LocalProposalSampler`1
member.summary: A method which samples datapoints from a proposal distribution given an initial sample. The implementation of this sampler is stateless: no variables are saved between two calls to Sample. This proposal is different from in that it samples locally around an initial point. In other words, it makes a small local move rather than producing a global sample from the proposal.
member.typeparam: The type of the datapoints.
member.param: The initial sample.
member.returns: A sample from the proposal distribution.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.MetropolisHastingsSampler`1
member.summary:
Metropolis-Hastings sampling produces samples from distribution P by sampling from a proposal distribution Q and accepting/rejecting based on the density of P. Metropolis-Hastings sampling doesn't require that the proposal distribution Q is symmetric in comparison to . It does need to be able to evaluate the proposal sampler's log density though. All densities are required to be in log space.
The Metropolis-Hastings sampler is a stateful sampler. It keeps track of where it currently is in the domain of the distribution P.
member.typeparam: The type of samples this sampler produces.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.Mcmc.UnivariateSliceSampler
member.summary:
Slice sampling produces samples from distribution P by uniformly sampling from under the pdf of P using a technique described in "Slice Sampling", R. Neal, 2003. All densities are required to be in log space.
The slice sampler is a stateful sampler. It keeps track of where it currently is in the domain of the distribution P.

member.name: T:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.RunningStatistics
member.summary: Running statistics accumulator, allows updating by adding values or by combining two accumulators.

member.summary: Estimates the unbiased population variance from the provided samples. On a dataset of size N will use an N-1 normalizer (Bessel's correction). Returns NaN if data has less than two entries or if any entry is NaN.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.RunningStatistics.PopulationVariance
member.summary: Evaluates the variance from the provided full population. On a dataset of size N will use an N normalizer and would thus be biased if applied to a subset. Returns NaN if data is empty or if any entry is NaN.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.RunningStatistics.StandardDeviation
member.summary: Estimates the unbiased population standard deviation from the provided samples. On a dataset of size N will use an N-1 normalizer (Bessel's correction). Returns NaN if data has less than two entries or if any entry is NaN.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.RunningStatistics.PopulationStandardDeviation
member.summary: Evaluates the standard deviation from the provided full population. On a dataset of size N will use an N normalizer and would thus be biased if applied to a subset. Returns NaN if data is empty or if any entry is NaN.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.RunningStatistics.Skewness
member.summary: Estimates the unbiased population skewness from the provided samples. Uses a normalizer (Bessel's correction; type 2). Returns NaN if data has less than three entries or if any entry is NaN.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.RunningStatistics.PopulationSkewness
member.summary: Evaluates the population skewness from the full population. Does not use a normalizer and would thus be biased if applied to a subset (type 1). Returns NaN if data has less than two entries or if any entry is NaN.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.RunningStatistics.Kurtosis
member.summary: Estimates the unbiased population excess kurtosis from the provided samples. Uses a normalizer (Bessel's correction; type 2). Returns NaN if data has less than four entries or if any entry is NaN.

member.name: P:MathNet.Numerics.Statistics.RunningStatistics.PopulationKurtosis
member.summary: Evaluates the population excess kurtosis from the full population. Does not use a normalizer and would thus be biased if applied to a subset (type 1). Returns NaN if data has less than three entries or if any entry is NaN.
